Client2Vec: Improving Federated Learning by Distribution Shifts Aware Client Indexing

Yongxin Guo1,2, Lin Wang1,2, Xiaoying Tang1,2,3, Tao Lin4,5
1School of Science and Engineering, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen,
Guangdong, 518172, P.R. China
2The Shenzhen Institute of Artificial Intelligence and Robotics for Society
3The Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Future Networks of Intelligence
4Research Center for Industries of the Future, Westlake University
5School of Engineering, Westlake University
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) is a privacy-preserving distributed machine learning paradigm. Nonetheless, the substantial distribution shifts among clients pose a considerable challenge to the performance of current FL algorithms. To mitigate this challenge, various methods have been proposed to enhance the FL training process.

This paper endeavors to tackle the issue of data heterogeneity from another perspectiveâ€”by improving FL algorithms prior to the actual training stage. Specifically, we introduce the Client2Vec mechanism, which generates a unique client index for each client before the commencement of FL training. Subsequently, we leverage the generated client index to enhance the subsequent FL training process. To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed Client2Vec method, we conduct three case studies that assess the impact of the client index on the FL training process. These case studies encompass enhanced client sampling, model aggregation, and local training. Extensive experiments conducted on diverse datasets and model architectures show the efficacy of Client2Vec across all three case studies. Our code is avaliable at https://github.com/LINs-lab/client2vec.

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) is an emerging machine learning paradigm that preserves clientsâ€™ privacy by only exchanging model parameters between clients and server, and maintains the local data not exchanged. As the de facto algorithm in FL, FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2016) proposes to use local SGD to improve the communication efficiency of FL. However, the non-i.i.d.Â nature of local distributions significantly reduces the performance of FL algorithmsÂ (Lin etÂ al., 2020b; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020b; Li etÂ al., 2020). Despite the great success of existing methods in addressing the non-i.i.d.Â problem in FLÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021; Acar etÂ al., 2020), most existing studies center on the training process of FL by improving the key stages of the FL training, such as client samplingÂ (Fraboni etÂ al., 2021; Luo etÂ al., 2022; Wang etÂ al., 2023), model aggregationÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2019; Lin etÂ al., 2020a; Chen etÂ al., 2023), and local trainingÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020, 2021).

An additional line of research in FL aims to find efficient methods to improve the performance before the training stage. Yet only a limited number of works exist, either utilizing dataset distillation before the FL trainingÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2023), or generating global shared synthetic pseudo-dataÂ (Guo etÂ al., 2023b; Tang etÂ al., 2022). Despite promising, these approaches incur additional computation costs on local devices with a limited number of applicable scenarios and are incompatible with other FL training stages like client sampling and model aggregation.

Taking inspiration from the Word2Vec technique in Natural Language Processing (NLP) tasksÂ (Mikolov etÂ al., 2013) and domain indexing in Domain Generalization tasksÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2022), we introduce a novel mechanism below, namely Client2Vec. Client2Vec generates an index vector for each client, serving as their identity by incorporating information about the clientâ€™s local data distribution. These vectors are used to measure label and feature distribution shifts among clients, seamlessly integrate into the FL training pipeline, and allows efficiently (1) operating independently of the FL training process, (2) combining with existing FL methods, while imposing a minimal additional computational load on local devices, and (3) enhancing FL training performance throughout all stages.

Our contributions can be summarized as follows:

  • â€¢

    We explore a novel mechanism in FL called Client2Vec, which involves creating an index vector for each client before the FL training phase. These vectors incorporate information about the local distribution of clients and subsequently enhance the FL training process.

  • â€¢

    We present the Distribution Shifts Aware Index Generation Network (DSA-IGN), a network specifically designed to generate the client index prior to FL training. Our visualization results demonstrate the effectiveness of the client index in measuring the similarities in clientsâ€™ local distributions.

  • â€¢

    We conduct three case studies, including client sampling, model aggregation, and local training, to illustrate the potential and effectiveness of the generated client index. Our experiments, conducted on various datasets and model architectures, consistently demonstrate significant performance improvements with the use of Client2Vec.

2 Related Works

Information sharing in FL.

Federated Learning (FL) is a distributed training methodology where local data is retained and not exchanged between the central server and clientsÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020b, a; Guo etÂ al., 2023b; Jiang & Lin, 2023). FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2016; Lin etÂ al., 2020b), a foundational algorithm, uses local Stochastic Gradient Descent (local SGD) to reduce communication. Nevertheless, the performance of FL algorithms is substantially impeded by distribution shifts among clients. To address distribution shift in FL, existing works share local distribution statisticsÂ (Shin etÂ al., 2020; Zhou & Konukoglu, 2022), data representationsÂ (Hao etÂ al., 2021; Tan etÂ al., 2022), and prediction logitsÂ (Chang etÂ al., 2019; Luo etÂ al., 2021). FedMixÂ (Yoon etÂ al., 2020) and FedBRÂ (Guo etÂ al., 2023b) enhance local training with privacy-protected augmentation data. VHLÂ (Tang etÂ al., 2022) employs randomly initialized generative models to produce virtual data, regularizing local features to closely align with those of same-class virtual data. FedFedÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2023) proposes a dataset distillation method, amalgamating distilled datasets into all clientsâ€™ local datasets to mitigate distribution shifts. Compared to existing methods, Client2Vec has the following advantages: (1) decouples index generation from FL training, reducing FL training load; (2) generates one client index per client, improving efficiency; (3) contributes to the entire FL training process, including client sampling, model aggregation, and local training.

Domain indexing.

Domain Generalization (DG) tackles cross-domain generalization by generating domain-invariant features. While conventional DG methods strive to make a data pointâ€™s latent representation independent of its domain identity using a one-hot vectorÂ (Ganin etÂ al., 2016; Tzeng etÂ al., 2017; Zhao etÂ al., 2017), recent studies propose using real-value scalars or vectors as domain indices to improve performanceÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020; Xu etÂ al., 2021). However, obtaining domain indices may be impractical. To address this, Xu etÂ al. (2022) introduced variational domain indexing (VDI) to infer domain indices without prior knowledge. Yet, challenges arise when applying VDI to FL due to communication costs, privacy concerns, and neglect of label shifts. Further discussions on related works can be found in AppendixÂ B.

3 Client2Vec: Distribution Shifts Aware Client Indexing

In this section, we introduce Client2Vec, a mechanism that generates an index vector for each client, representing their identity and incorporating information about their local distribution. The client index, which considers both label and feature distribution shifts, is defined in SectionÂ 3.1. We present the Distribution Shifts Aware Index Generation Network (DSA-IGN) in SectionÂ 3.2, which generates the client index based on the specified criteria. Visualization examples of the generated client index are provided in SectionÂ 3.3.

3.1 Client Index

We consider the FL setting with Mğ‘€M clients, where each client iğ‘–i possesses Nisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–N_{i} data samples. The jğ‘—j-th data sample of client iğ‘–i is represented as (ğ±i,j,yi,j)subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—(\mathbf{x}_{i,j},y_{i,j}).

Sample index and Client index.

To ensure that the client index conveys information about all data samples within the client, we first generate the sample index ğ®i,jsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{u}_{i,j} as the index vector for the data sample (ğ±i,j,yi,j)subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—(\mathbf{x}_{i,j},y_{i,j}). The client index ğœ·isubscriptğœ·ğ‘–\bm{\beta}_{i} is then computed as the average of all data samples for client iğ‘–i: ğœ·i=1Niâ€‹âˆ‘j=1Niğ®i,jsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—\bm{\beta}_{i}=\frac{1}{N_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{N_{i}}\mathbf{u}_{i,j}.

For FL scenarios where feature and label shifts occur simultaneously, the sample index ğ®i,jsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{u}_{i,j} consists of two parts: sample feature index ğ®i,jfâˆˆâ„disuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘“superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{f}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{i}} and sample label index ğ®i,jlâˆˆâ„disuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘™superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{l}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{i}}, encoding the feature and label information of the data sample (ğ±i,j,yi,j)subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—(\mathbf{x}_{i,j},y_{i,j}), respectively. Similarly, the client index ğœ·isubscriptğœ·ğ‘–\bm{\beta}_{i} is represented as ğœ·i=[ğœ·if;ğœ·il]âˆˆâ„2â€‹disubscriptğœ·ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘™superscriptâ„2subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–\bm{\beta}_{i}=[\bm{\beta}_{i}^{f};\bm{\beta}_{i}^{l}]\in\mathbb{R}^{2d_{i}}, where ğœ·ifâˆˆâ„disuperscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘“superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–\bm{\beta}_{i}^{f}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{i}} is the client feature index, and ğœ·ilâˆˆâ„disuperscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘™superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–\bm{\beta}_{i}^{l}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{i}} is the client label index.

However, obtaining client and sample indices may not always be trivial in practice. To address this, we extend the domain index idea inÂ Xu etÂ al. (2022) and define the expected properties of sample index ğ®i,jsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{u}_{i,j} and client index ğœ·isubscriptğœ·ğ‘–\bm{\beta}_{i} below.

Definition 3.1 (Sample Index).

Given the data sample (ğ±i,j,yi,j)subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—(\mathbf{x}_{i,j},y_{i,j}) and its corresponding encoding ğ³i,jsubscriptğ³ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{z}_{i,j}, which encode information that can be used to predict yi,jsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—y_{i,j}, the sample index ğ®i,jsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{u}_{i,j} of data sample (ğ±i,j,yi,j)subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—(\mathbf{x}_{i,j},y_{i,j}) is expected to satisfy the following properties:

  • â€¢

    Independence between ui,jfsuperscriptsubscriptuijf\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{f} and zi,jsubscriptzij\mathbf{z}_{i,j}. Sample feature index ğ®i,jfsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘“\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{f} is independent of client-invariant data encoding ğ³i,jsubscriptğ³ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{z}_{i,j}. This aims to encourage the sample feature index ğ®i,jfsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘“\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{f} to encode the client-dependent informationâ€”specifically, the distinct information about the clientâ€™s local distribution, and unrelated to label prediction.

  • â€¢

    Maximizing information in ui,jlsuperscriptsubscriptuijl\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{l} and zi,jsubscriptzij\mathbf{z}_{i,j} for label prediction. The data encoding ğ³i,jsubscriptğ³ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{z}_{i,j} and sample label index ğ®i,jlsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘™\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{l} should contain as much information as possible to predict label yğ‘¦y.

  • â€¢

    Information Preservation of ui,jfsuperscriptsubscriptuijf\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{f} and zi,jsubscriptzij\mathbf{z}_{i,j}. Data encoding ğ³i,jsubscriptğ³ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{z}_{i,j} and sample feature index ğ®i,jfsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘“\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{f} preserves as much information as possible to recover data ğ±i,jsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{x}_{i,j}.

Remark 3.2.

Different from the definitions of domain index outlined in Xu etÂ al. (2022) (refer to DefinitionÂ C.1), DefinitionÂ 3.1 encompasses both label and feature distribution shifts by introducing the sample label index ğ®i,jlsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘™\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{l}. Additionally, generating domain-level index in DefinitionÂ C.1 requires to gather all sample indices ğ®i,jsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{u}_{i,j} from various data sources. We simplify this procedure and calculate the client index as ğ›ƒi=1Niâ€‹âˆ‘j=1Niğ®i,jsubscriptğ›ƒğ‘–1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—\bm{\beta}_{i}\!=\!\frac{1}{N_{i}}\sum_{j=1}^{N_{i}}\mathbf{u}_{i,j}.

3.2 Generating Client Index

In this section, we describe the generation of ğœ·isubscriptğœ·ğ‘–\bm{\beta}_{i} and ğ®i,jsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{u}_{i,j} based on DefinitionÂ 3.1, as depicted in FigureÂ 1. We use image datasets for clarity, and details for language datasets can be found in AppendixÂ D.1.

Encoding data using CLIP.

Since the client index, denoted as Î²isubscriptğ›½ğ‘–\beta_{i}, is computed as an average across sample indices ğ®i,jsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{u}_{i,j}, the primary challenge in generating the client index lies in generating these sample indices ğ®i,jsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{u}_{i,j}. According to DefinitionÂ 3.1, we can observe that the sample label index ğ®i,jlsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘™\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{l} solely encodes label information, while the sample feature index encodes image feature information independently of label information. Consequently, to generate the sample index, we must devise a method that maps label information and image information into the same space, facilitating the extraction of label-dependent sample label index ğ®i,jlsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘™\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{l} and label-independent sample feature index ğ®i,jfsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘“\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{f}.

We propose to leverage CLIPÂ (Radford etÂ al., 2021) to ease the index generation process. CLIP is a pre-trained cross-modality model that contains an image encoder and a text encoder, aligning image and text embedding. As shown in FigureÂ 1, for a given input image-label pairs (ğ±i,j,yi,j)subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—(\mathbf{x}_{i,j},y_{i,j}), we utilize a CLIP image encoder to produce image embedding ğƒi,jsubscriptğƒğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{D}_{i,j} and a text encoder to generate label embedding ğ‹i,jsubscriptğ‹ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{L}_{i,j}:

  • â€¢

    Label Embedding ğ‹i,jsubscriptğ‹ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{L}_{i,j}: The ğ‹i,jsubscriptğ‹ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{L}_{i,j} only encodes label descriptions such as â€œA photo of a/an {object}â€. Therefore, we use ğ‹i,jsubscriptğ‹ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{L}_{i,j} as the embedding that only contains label information, which is naturally invariant among clients.

  • â€¢

    Image embedding ğƒi,jsubscriptğƒğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{D}_{i,j}: The ğƒi,jsubscriptğƒğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{D}_{i,j} is extracted from the whole image, serving as a compact feature containing both client-independent (label information) and client-specific (background, style, etc.) features.

Consequently, the original local dataset ğ’Ÿi={(ğ±i,j,yi,j)}subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathcal{D}_{i}=\{(\mathbf{x}_{i,j},y_{i,j})\} is transformed into the CLIP embedding set â„°i={(ğƒi,j,ğ‹i,j)}subscriptâ„°ğ‘–subscriptğƒğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‹ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathcal{E}_{i}=\{(\mathbf{D}_{i,j},\mathbf{L}_{i,j})\}. The â„°isubscriptâ„°ğ‘–\mathcal{E}_{i} is then utilized to generate the index. Note that other cross-modality models, such as BLIPÂ (Li etÂ al., 2022) and BLIP2Â (Li etÂ al., 2023a), can also align vision and language like CLIP. Exploring the effectiveness of these models could be a valuable future research direction.

Generating sample indices using CLIP embedding and DSA-IGN.

Given that ğ‹i,jsubscriptğ‹ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{L}_{i,j} only encodes label information, we directly set ğ®i,jl=ğ‹i,jsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘™subscriptğ‹ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{l}=\mathbf{L}_{i,j}. On the contrary, by DefinitionÂ 3.1, the sample feature index ğ®i,jfsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘“\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{f} needs to encode label-invariant client-specific information. Thus, we decompose ğƒi,jsubscriptğƒğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{D}_{i,j}â€”which contains both label and client-specific informationâ€”to generate ğ®i,jfsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘“\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{f} while isolating the client-specific information from ğƒi,jsubscriptğƒğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{D}_{i,j}.

The entire process of generating the sample feature index is achieved by training the Distribution Shifts Aware Generation Network (DSA-IGN). The training process of DSA-IGN includes three components, corresponding to the three rules in DefinitionÂ 3.1:

  • â€¢

    Decompose CLIP image embedding ğƒi,jsubscriptğƒğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{D}_{i,j}. We decompose ğƒi,jsubscriptğƒğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{D}_{i,j} to sample feature index ğ®i,jfsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘“\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{f} and data encoding ğ³i,jsubscriptğ³ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{z}_{i,j}. Regularization is applied to ensure orthogonality between ğ®i,jfsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘“\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{f} and ğ³i,jsubscriptğ³ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{z}_{i,j}, ensuring their independence. The decomposition block can be any non-linear neural network architecture, and we use a three-layer transformer encoder as the decomposition block for the sake of simplicity111 Each transformer encoder layer will have 8 attention heads and the dimension of the model is 32. More details about the network architectures of DSA-IGN can be found in AppendixÂ D.2. .

  • â€¢

    Aligning the data encoding ğ³i,jsubscriptğ³ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{z}_{i,j} and ğ‹i,jsubscriptğ‹ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{L}_{i,j} to ensure label sensitivity of ğ³i,jsubscriptğ³ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{z}_{i,j}. We force ğ³i,jsubscriptğ³ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{z}_{i,j} to have a large cosine similarity with the label embedding ğ‹i,jsubscriptğ‹ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{L}_{i,j}, ensuring that ğ³i,jsubscriptğ³ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{z}_{i,j} encodes as much information as possible to predict the label yi,jsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘—y_{i,j}.

  • â€¢

    Reconstruct CLIP image embedding ğƒi,jsubscriptğƒğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{D}_{i,j}. To ensure that ğ®i,jfsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘“\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{f} and ğ³i,jsubscriptğ³ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{z}_{i,j} retain all the information from the CLIP image embedding ğƒi,jsubscriptğƒğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{D}_{i,j}, we utilize ğ®i,jfsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘“\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{f} and ğ³i,jsubscriptğ³ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{z}_{i,j} for the purpose of reconstructing ğƒi,jsubscriptğƒğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{D}_{i,j}. In detail, we begin by concatenating ğ®i,jfsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘“\mathbf{u}_{i,j}^{f} and ğ³i,jsubscriptğ³ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{z}_{i,j}, followed by projecting the resultant vector onto ğƒ~â€‹i,j~ğƒğ‘–ğ‘—\tilde{\mathbf{D}}{i,j}, and subsequently minimizing the distance between the reconstructed embedding ğƒ~â€‹i,j~ğƒğ‘–ğ‘—\tilde{\mathbf{D}}{i,j} and the original CLIP image embedding ğƒi,jsubscriptğƒğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{D}_{i,j}. Experiments on various projection layer architectures can be found in AppendixÂ D.3.

Objective functions of DSA-IGN.

We define the following objective function:

    â„’reconsubscriptâ„’recon\mathcal{L}_{\text{recon}} for information preservation. It is defined as the mean squared distance between the reconstructed embedding ğƒ~i,jsubscript~ğƒğ‘–ğ‘—\tilde{\mathbf{D}}_{i,j} and the original CLIP image embedding ğƒi,jsubscriptğƒğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{D}_{i,j}.

  • â€¢

    â„’divsubscriptâ„’div\mathcal{L}_{\text{div}} is introduced to ensure stable training outcomes by promoting diversity in ğ®iâ€‹jfsuperscriptsubscriptğ®ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘“\mathbf{u}_{ij}^{f} across different samples within the same batch. BğµB is the batch-size here.

Optimizing Client2Vec.

We consider two training strategies, namely Global and Federated explained below:

  • â€¢

    Global: Each client uploads one batch (128 samples) of (ğƒi,j,ğ‹i,j)subscriptğƒğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‹ğ‘–ğ‘—(\mathbf{D}_{i,j},\mathbf{L}_{i,j}) pairs to the server. The server trains the DSA-IGN using the collected pairs from all clients and then sends the trained DSA-IGN to clients for generating client index.

  • â€¢

    Federated: The DSA-IGN is trained using all clientsâ€™ local data through FedAvg. In each communication round, the server randomly selects 10% of clients, and the local epoch number is set to 10.

3.3 Visualization Examples of Client Index

In this section, we visualize some examples of the generated client index on the DomainNet datasetÂ (Peng etÂ al., 2019a). DomainNet contains data from 6 different domains, where data belonging to different domains have significant feature shifts. We chose 50 out of 345 available classes, with each domain randomly divided into 10 clients. Then the 6 domains will result in a total of 60 clients. Clients 0 to 9 correspond to the first feature domain, clients 10 to 19 to the second, and so forth, with clients 51 to 59 representing the last feature domain. Clients from various domains experience feature shifts and possess varying sample sizes due to differences in the number of samples within each domain.

Similarity of client indices among different clients.

As the distribution shifts among clients mainly come from the feature shifts among domains, in FigureÂ 3 we depict the similarities of the client index ğœ·isubscriptğœ·ğ‘–\bm{\beta}_{i} and the client feature index ğœ·ifsuperscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘“\bm{\beta}_{i}^{f} across clients, employing both Global and Federated training strategies. We have the following observations:

  • â€¢

    Clients sharing the same feature domain show similar client indices. We observe the similarities between client index ğœ·isubscriptğœ·ğ‘–\bm{\beta}_{i} and client feature index ğœ·ifsuperscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘“\bm{\beta}_{i}^{f} approach 1.01.01.0 for clients within the same feature domain. Conversely, clients belonging to different feature domains have large distances regarding the client feature index ğœ·ifsuperscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘“\bm{\beta}_{i}^{f}. This highlights the effectiveness of our method in learning meaningful information about clientsâ€™ local distribution.

  • â€¢

    Both the Global and Federated training strategies produce client indices that encode meaningful information about client distribution. We note that both the Global and Federated training strategies can generate similar client indices for clients with the same feature domain. Moreover, the indices generated by the Global strategy exhibit a more clear boundary among domains.

Inter-Domain Similarity Assessment.

Utilizing the feature index ğœ·ifsuperscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘“\bm{\beta}_{i}^{f} for clients, we quantify similarity across different domains. FigureÂ 2 illustrates the average cosine similarities of client feature index ğœ·ifsuperscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘“\bm{\beta}_{i}^{f} between clients belonging to different domains. The results align with human intuitions, with the â€œRealâ€ domain showing greater proximity to â€œClipartâ€, â€œPaintingâ€, and â€œSketchâ€, while exhibiting significant differences from â€œInfographâ€ and â€œQuickdrawâ€. These findings validate the effectiveness of our generated client index.

4 Improving FL via Client2Vec

In this section, we showcase improving the FL training process by leveraging the trained client index ğœ·isubscriptğœ·ğ‘–\bm{\beta}_{i}. Specifically, we explore three case studies aimed at refining crucial aspects of the FL training pipeline: client sampling, model aggregation, and local training.

Case study 1: improved client sampling.

The client index, ğœ·isubscriptğœ·ğ‘–\bm{\beta}_{i}, is a natural metric for measuring distance between clients. Motivated by the theoretical findings in CyCPÂ (Cho etÂ al., 2023) and empirical observations in class incremental learningÂ (He etÂ al., 2022)â€”where a smaller distance among client groups sampled in adjacent rounds improves performanceâ€”we propose a greedy sampling approach.

In round tğ‘¡t, let ğ’tâˆ’1superscriptğ’ğ‘¡1\mathcal{C}^{t-1} be the set of clients selected in round tâˆ’1ğ‘¡1t-1. Clients with greater similarity to those in ğ’tâˆ’1superscriptğ’ğ‘¡1\mathcal{C}^{t-1} will have a higher probability of being selected. Specifically, the sampling probability for client iğ‘–i is calculated as:

pit=expâ¡(Sâ€‹(ğœ·i,ğ’tâˆ’1)/Ï„)âˆ‘j=1Nexpâ¡(Sâ€‹(ğœ·j,ğ’tâˆ’1)/Ï„).superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¡Ssubscriptğœ·ğ‘–superscriptğ’ğ‘¡1ğœsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘Ssubscriptğœ·ğ‘—superscriptğ’ğ‘¡1ğœ\displaystyle p_{i}^{t}=\frac{\exp(\text{S}(\bm{\beta}_{i},\mathcal{C}^{t-1})/\tau)}{\sum_{j=1}^{N}\exp(\text{S}(\bm{\beta}_{j},\mathcal{C}^{t-1})/\tau)}\,. (1)

Here, Ï„ğœ\tau is the hyper-parameter controlling the sampling distribution shape, and the similarity function Sğ‘†S is defined as:

Sâ€‹(ğœ·i,ğ’tâˆ’1)=12â€‹Ntâˆ’1â€‹âˆ‘j=1|ğ’tâˆ’1|Njâ€‹(simâ€‹(ğœ·if,ğœ·jf)+simâ€‹(ğœ·il,ğœ·jl)),Ssubscriptğœ·ğ‘–superscriptğ’ğ‘¡112superscriptğ‘ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1superscriptğ’ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘ğ‘—simsuperscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘—ğ‘“simsuperscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘—ğ‘™\displaystyle\text{S}(\bm{\beta}_{i},\mathcal{C}^{t-1})=\frac{1}{2N^{t-1}}\sum_{j=1}^{|\mathcal{C}^{t-1}|}N_{j}\left(\text{sim}(\bm{\beta}_{i}^{f},\bm{\beta}_{j}^{f})+\text{sim}(\bm{\beta}_{i}^{l},\bm{\beta}_{j}^{l})\right)\,,

where Ntâˆ’1=âˆ‘jâˆˆğ’tâˆ’1Njsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘—superscriptğ’ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘ğ‘—N^{t-1}=\sum_{j\in\mathcal{C}^{t-1}}N_{j}, and Njsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—N_{j} is the number of samples of client jğ‘—j. The â€œsimâ€ refers to cosine similarity. In practical implementation, to avoid resampling identical clients, those already sampled within M2â€‹|ğ’tâˆ’1|ğ‘€2superscriptğ’ğ‘¡1\frac{M}{2|\mathcal{C}^{t-1}|} rounds will have pitsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¡p_{i}^{t} set to 00, where Mğ‘€M is the total number of clients.

Case study 2: improved model aggregation.

The enhanced model aggregation strategy follows the same idea as client sampling. In detail, we assign higher aggregation weights to clients with greater similarity to those in previous rounds. To achieve this, motivated by the Multiplicative Weight Update algorithm (MWU)Â Arora etÂ al. (2012), we define the following optimization problem for deriving the aggregation weights pi,gtsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘”ğ‘¡p_{i,g}^{t}.

Case study 3: improved local training.

According to DefinitionÂ 3.1, the generated client feature index ğœ·ifsuperscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘“\bm{\beta}_{i}^{f} contains client-specific information unrelated to label information. Thus, to promote label sensitivity in local features, the local features should be independent of the client feature index ğœ·ifsuperscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘“\bm{\beta}_{i}^{f}. To ensure this, we design the subsequent local objective function to enforce orthogonality between the trained local features ğ³i,jsubscriptğ³ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{z}_{i,j} and the client feature index ğœ·ifsuperscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘“\bm{\beta}_{i}^{f} for any client iğ‘–i.

â„’â€‹(ğ±,y)=â„’clsâ€‹(ğ±,y)+â„’orthâ€‹(ğ³P,ğf)+â„’distâ€‹(ğ³,ğ³P),â„’ğ±ğ‘¦subscriptâ„’clsğ±ğ‘¦subscriptâ„’orthsubscriptğ³ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğğ‘“subscriptâ„’distğ³subscriptğ³ğ‘ƒ\displaystyle\mathcal{L}(\mathbf{x},y)=\mathcal{L}_{\text{cls}}(\mathbf{x},y)+\mathcal{L}_{\text{orth}}(\mathbf{z}_{P},\mathbf{B}^{f})+\mathcal{L}_{\text{dist}}(\mathbf{z},\mathbf{z}_{P})\,, (4)

where ğf=[ğœ·1f,â‹¯,ğœ·Nf]superscriptğğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğœ·1ğ‘“â‹¯superscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘ğ‘“\mathbf{B}^{f}=[\bm{\beta}_{1}^{f},\cdots,\bm{\beta}_{N}^{f}], ğ³ğ³\mathbf{z} represents local features, and ğ³Pâˆˆâ„disubscriptğ³ğ‘ƒsuperscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–\mathbf{z}_{P}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{i}} is the projected feature. To handle dimension mismatches between local features ğ³i,jsubscriptğ³ğ‘–ğ‘—\mathbf{z}_{i,j} and client feature indices ğœ·ifsuperscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘“\bm{\beta}_{i}^{f}, we initially project ğ³âˆˆâ„dğ³superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{z}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} to ğ³Pâˆˆâ„disubscriptğ³ğ‘ƒsuperscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–\mathbf{z}_{P}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{i}} using a trainable matrix ğâˆˆâ„dÃ—diğsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘–\mathbf{P}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d_{i}} (see FigureÂ 4). An orthogonal loss term â„’orth=âˆ¥ğ³Pâ€‹ğfâˆ¥1subscriptâ„’orthsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ³ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğğ‘“1\mathcal{L}_{\text{orth}}=\left\lVert\mathbf{z}_{P}\mathbf{B}^{f}\right\rVert_{1} further encourages orthogonality between ğ³Psubscriptğ³ğ‘ƒ\mathbf{z}_{P} and ğfsuperscriptğğ‘“\mathbf{B}^{f}.

This term regulates the Kullback-Leibler divergence between the prediction logits of ğ³ğ³\mathbf{z} and that of ğ³Psubscriptğ³ğ‘ƒ\mathbf{z}_{P}.

5 Experiments

In this section, we investigate if the Client2Vec and the proposed three case studies can improve the FL algorithm performance. More detailed experiment settings and additional experimental results can be found in AppendixÂ D.

5.1 Experiment Settings

Datasets and models.

In this paper, we utilize three datasets: Shakespeare, CIFAR10, and DomainNet. Shakespeareâ€™s partition uses LEAF benchmarkâ€™s methodÂ (Caldas etÂ al., 2018). CIFAR10 is partitioned into 100 clients using Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA)Â (Yurochkin etÂ al., 2019; Hsu etÂ al., 2019) with Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1 for label distribution shifts. DomainNet randomly selects 50 classes from the total 345 and divides sub-datasets into 10 clients per domain, resulting in a total of 60 clients. Further dataset partition details are available in AppendixÂ D.2. We randomly select 10% of clients in each of the 100 communication rounds, with a fixed number of 5 local epochs. Additional hyper-parameter details can be found in AppendixÂ D.2.

Baseline Algorithms.

We have selected widely recognized FL baselines for our study, encompassing established methods such as FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2016), FedAvgMÂ (Hsu etÂ al., 2019), FedDynÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2021), and MoonÂ (Li etÂ al., 2021). Additionally, we have incorporated more recently introduced baselines, namely FedLCÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2022) and FedIIRÂ (Guo etÂ al., 2023a). It is important to note that FedIIR is specifically tailored for addressing feature shift tasks and, as a result, its evaluation is limited to the DomainNet dataset.

5.2 Numerical Results

Superior performance of Client2Vec on all three case studies.

In TableÂ 1, we evaluate Client2Vecâ€™s performance in three case studies: enhanced client sampling, improved model aggregation, and refined local training. The results reveal the following insights: (1) Each case study shows performance improvements across all baselines, highlighting the potential of generated client indices to enhance FL algorithms. (2) Enhanced local training provides the most significant performance boost, emphasizing the importance of refining local features for addressing distribution shifts. (3) The Federated strategy consistently matches the Global strategy in performance, except for improved client sampling, where the Global strategy surpasses, showcasing its superior capability in assessing client similarities (see FigureÂ 3). (4) The performance gain from improved model aggregation seems somewhat random compared to other case studies. This might be due to the shared intuition between improved client sampling and model aggregation, limiting further improvements when combining these approaches. However, solely using improved model aggregation consistently outperforms the original algorithms, as seen in FigureÂ 5(c) andÂ 5(d).

In summary, utilizing the client indices significantly boost the model performance. In practice, we can select which case studies to use, and we recommend combining all three case studies as this approach provides a stable and significant performance gain compared to the baseline algorithms.

All the components of Client2Vec are necessary.

In TableÂ 2, we conduct ablation studies on Client2Vec. The results indicate that: (1) The original Client2Vec achieves the highest final performance among different client vector candidates. Although feature average and class prototypes show potential for aiding in sampling, they cannot be readily employed in our local training phase, which significantly contributes to the effectiveness of the Client2Vec algorithm. (2) All three losses are essential for Client2Vecâ€™s effectiveness. The orthogonal loss notably enhances the local training phase, while removing the text align loss and reconstruction loss significantly diminishes model performance. (3) Both feature and label indices are vital for optimizing Client2Vecâ€™s performance. The absence of the feature index hinders improved local training. Additionally, since the CIFAR10 dataset is partitioned using the Dirichlet method, introducing label shifts instead of feature shifts, the label index is crucial for enhancing sampling and model aggregation performance in this context. (4) Orthogonal loss is crucial for achieving optimal performance in local training. Without it, local training fails to surpass the performance of the original FedAvg.

Ablation studies on the number of training epochs for Client2Vec.

We conduct ablation studies on the Client2Vec algorithm, varying the number of training epochs as shown in FigureÂ 5(a) andÂ 5(b). The results indicate that: (1) Client indices generated with 100 or 500 training epochs notably enhance FL algorithm performance. (2) Increasing the number of training epochs for Client2Vec does not consistently lead to better results, as 100 epochs achieve similar performance to 500 epochs in most cases.

Ablation studies on hyper-parameters of improved client sampling.

In FigureÂ 6(c) andÂ 6(d), we perform ablation studies on the heat parameter Ï„ğœ\tau in EqÂ (1). The results indicate that (1) algorithms with improved client sampling consistently outperform the original algorithms across various Ï„ğœ\tau values; (2) the optimal Ï„ğœ\tau value is smaller for client indices trained using the Federated strategy compared to the Global strategy. This observation aligns with our previous findings that Global strategy-trained client indices exhibit larger inter-client distances.

Ablation studies on hyper-parameters of improved local training.

In FigureÂ 6, ablation studies on the weight of the local regularization term (EqÂ (4)) were conducted. The findings suggest that: (1) Using weights of 1.01.01.0 for the Federated strategy and 5.05.05.0 for the Global strategy yields favorable results for all algorithms. (2) FedDyn exhibits higher resilience to changes in the weights of the local regularization terms.

Computation time comparison.

In TableÂ 3, we show the simulation time of Client2Vec and FedAvg. Results show that (1) The additional computational overhead for generating the client index is relatively insignificant compared to the subsequent training stage; (2) From the â€˜Total achieve FedAvg best performanceâ€™ column, Client2Vec requires less computational time to achieve comparable performance to FedAvg, particularly noticeable on larger-scale datasets such as DomainNet.

5.3 Ablation Studies on Various Model Architectures.

In TableÂ 4, we show how Client2Vec improves performance with different model architectures. Our results reveal that: (1) Client2Vec significantly boosts the performance of original algorithms in all settings, and (2) pre-trained models like MobileNet V2 and ResNet18 produce better results, while Client2Vec also enhances the performance of VIT models trained from scratch.

6 Conclusion and Future Works

In this paper, we explore the potential of enhancing FL algorithm performance through client index vectors. Our three case studies clearly demonstrate the significant improvement in FL algorithm performance achieved through client indices, highlighting client indexing as a valuable avenue for FL algorithm enhancement. Itâ€™s important to note that these case studies may not cover all FL training scenarios. Investigating the impact of client indices on other aspects, such as personalization and clustering, would be valuable.

Appendix B Related Works

Distribution shifts in FL.

Federated Learning (FL) is introduced as a methodology for training machine learning models in a distributed manner, wherein local data is retained and not exchanged between the central server and individual clients. FedAvgÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2016; Lin etÂ al., 2020b), serving as a foundational algorithm in this domain, advocates the use of local Stochastic Gradient Descent (local SGD) to alleviate the communication burden. Nevertheless, the performance of FL algorithms is substantially impeded by distribution shifts among clients. Addressing these local distribution shifts has emerged as a primary focus in FL researchÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020b, a; Guo etÂ al., 2023b; Jiang & Lin, 2023). Many existing works address label distribution shifts by incorporating additional regularization termsÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020b; Guo etÂ al., 2021; Lee etÂ al., 2022; Mendieta etÂ al., 2022), enhancing feature learningÂ (Tang etÂ al., 2022; Shi etÂ al., 2023; Li etÂ al., 2021; Zhou etÂ al., 2023), and improving classifiersÂ (Luo etÂ al., 2021; Li etÂ al., 2023c). Regarding feature distribution shifts, the majority of FL methods concentrate on the out-of-domain generalization problem. This objective aims to train robust models capable of generalizing to previously unseen feature distributionsÂ (Nguyen etÂ al., 2022; Li etÂ al., 2023b; Guo etÂ al., 2023a). Approaches include investigating special casesÂ (Reisizadeh etÂ al., 2020), integrating domain generalization algorithms in FL scenarios, such as domain-robust optimizationÂ (Mohri etÂ al., 2019; Deng etÂ al., 2021), and training domain-invariant featuresÂ (Peng etÂ al., 2019b; Wang etÂ al., 2022; Shen etÂ al., 2021; Sun etÂ al., 2022; Gan etÂ al., 2021). Notably, recent research has also considered concept shifts by leveraging clustering methodsÂ (Jothimurugesan etÂ al., 2022; guo2023fedconceptem; Guo etÂ al., 2023c). In this study, we address the challenge of distribution shifts in FL from another perspectiveâ€”enhancing the performance of FL algorithms prior to the training stage. Our approach holds the potential for seamless integration with the aforementioned algorithms, and consider both feature and label distribution shifts.

Information sharing in FL.

Various methods have been developed to address the challenge of distribution shifts among clientsÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2018; Jeong etÂ al., 2018; Long etÂ al., 2021). One approach involves the sharing of information among clients, such as the exchange of local distribution statisticsÂ (Shin etÂ al., 2020; Zhou & Konukoglu, 2022), data representationsÂ (Hao etÂ al., 2021; Tan etÂ al., 2022), and prediction logitsÂ (Chang etÂ al., 2019; Luo etÂ al., 2021). Additionally, techniques leveraging global proxy datasets have been introduced to enhance FL trainingÂ (Lin etÂ al., 2020a; Duan etÂ al., 2019). Notably, FedMixÂ (Yoon etÂ al., 2020) and FedBRÂ (Guo etÂ al., 2023b) generate privacy-protected augmentation data by averaging local batches, subsequently improving the local training process. VHLÂ (Tang etÂ al., 2022) employs randomly initialized generative models to produce virtual data, compelling local features to closely align with those of same-class virtual data. FedFedÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2023) proposes a dataset distillation method, amalgamating distilled datasets into all clientsâ€™ local datasets to mitigate distribution shifts. In comparison to existing approaches, Client2Vec presents several advantages: (1) the index generation process is decoupled from the FL training process, thereby avoiding any additional burden on FL training; (2) Client2Vec generates only one index vector per client, enhancing efficiency; (3) Client2Vec contributes to the whole FL training stage, encompassing client sampling, model aggregation, and local training processes.

Appendix C Preliminaries

In this section, we present essential background information on the techniques and definitions employed in this paper to facilitate comprehension.

C.1 Domain Indexing

The Domain Generalization (DG) tasks are designed to address the cross-domain generalization problem by generating domain-invariant features. Typically, DG methods aim to establish independence between a data pointâ€™s latent representation and its domain identity, represented by a one-hot vector indicating the source domainÂ (Ganin etÂ al., 2016; Tzeng etÂ al., 2017; Zhao etÂ al., 2017). However, recent studies have demonstrated that utilizing a domain index, which is a real-value scalar (or vector) embedding domain semantics, as a substitute for domain identity, significantly enhances domain generalization performanceÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2020; Xu etÂ al., 2021).

For example, in the work by Wang etÂ al. (2020), sleeping stage prediction models were adapted across patients with varying ages, using "age" as the domain index. This approach yielded superior performance compared to traditional models that categorized patients into groups based on age, employing discrete group IDs as domain identities.

Nevertheless, obtaining domain indices may not always be feasible in practical scenarios. To overcome this challenge, Xu etÂ al. (2022) formally defined the domain index and introduced variational domain indexing (VDI) to infer domain indices without prior knowledge. The definition of the domain index in Xu etÂ al. (2022) is illustrated as follows.

Definition of domain index.

Consider the unsupervised domain adaptation setting involving a total of Nğ‘N domains, each characterized by a domain identity kâˆˆğ’¦=[N]â‰œ{1,â€¦,N}ğ‘˜ğ’¦delimited-[]ğ‘â‰œ1â€¦ğ‘k\in\mathcal{K}=[N]\triangleq\{1,\ldots,N\}. Here, kğ‘˜k belongs to either the source domain identity set ğ’¦ssubscriptğ’¦ğ‘ \mathcal{K}_{s} or the target domain identity set ğ’¦tsubscriptğ’¦ğ‘¡\mathcal{K}_{t}. Every domain kğ‘˜k comprises Dksubscriptğ·ğ‘˜D_{k} data points. The task involves nğ‘›n labeled data points {(ğ±â€‹is,yis,kis)}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptğ±superscriptğ‘–ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘–1ğ‘›\left\{(\mathbf{x}i^{s},y_{i}^{s},k_{i}^{s})\right\}_{i=1}^{n} originating from source domains (kisâˆˆğ’¦s)superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘ subscriptğ’¦ğ‘ \left(k_{i}^{s}\in\mathcal{K}_{s}\right) and mğ‘šm unlabeled data points {ğ±â€‹it,kit}i=1msuperscriptsubscriptğ±superscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘–1ğ‘š\left\{\mathbf{x}i^{t},k_{i}^{t}\right\}_{i=1}^{m} from target domains (kitâˆˆğ’¦t)superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğ’¦ğ‘¡\left(k_{i}^{t}\in\mathcal{K}_{t}\right). The objectives are twofold: (1) predict the labels {yit}i=1msuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘–1ğ‘š\left\{y_{i}^{t}\right\}_{i=1}^{m} for the target domain data, and (2) deduce global domain indices ğœ·kâˆˆâ„BÎ²subscriptğœ·ğ‘˜superscriptâ„subscriptğµğ›½\bm{\beta}_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{B_{\beta}} for each domain and local domain indices ğ®iâˆˆâ„Busubscriptğ®ğ‘–superscriptâ„subscriptğµğ‘¢\mathbf{u}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{B_{u}} for each data point. It is important to note that each domain possesses a single global domain index but multiple local domain indices, with one corresponding to each data point in the domain. The data encoding generated from an encoder that takes ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} as input is represented as ğ³âˆˆâ„Bzğ³superscriptâ„subscriptğµğ‘§\mathbf{z}\in\mathbb{R}^{B_{z}}. The mutual information is denoted by Iâ€‹(â‹…;â‹…)ğ¼â‹…â‹…I(\cdot;\cdot).

Definition C.1 (Domain Index).

Given data ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} and label yğ‘¦y, a domain-level variable ğ›ƒğ›ƒ\bm{\beta} and a data-level variable ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u} are called global and local domain indices, respectively, if there exists a data encoding ğ³ğ³\mathbf{z} such that the following holds:

  • â€¢

    Independence between ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta} and ğ³ğ³\mathbf{z}: Global domain index Î²ğ›½\beta is independent of data encoding ğ³ğ³\mathbf{z}, i.e., ğœ·âŸ‚âŸ‚ğ³\bm{\beta}\perp\!\!\!\!\perp\mathbf{z}, or equivalently Iâ€‹(ğœ·;ğ³)=0ğ¼ğœ·ğ³0I(\bm{\beta};\mathbf{z})=0. This is to encourage domain-invariant data encoding ğ³ğ³\mathbf{z}.

  • â€¢

    Information Preservation of ğ³ğ³\mathbf{z}: Data encoding ğ³ğ³\mathbf{z}, local domain index ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u}, and global domain index ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta} preserves as much information on ğ±ğ±\mathbf{x} as possible, i.e., maximizing Iâ€‹(ğ±;ğ®,ğœ·,ğ³)ğ¼ğ±ğ®ğœ·ğ³I(\mathbf{x};\mathbf{u},\bm{\beta},\mathbf{z}). This is to prevent ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta} and ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u} from collapsing to trivial solutions.

  • â€¢

    Label Sensitivity of ğ³ğ³\mathbf{z}: The data encoding ğ³ğ³\mathbf{z} should contain as much information on the label yğ‘¦y as possible to maximize prediction power, i.e., maximizing Iâ€‹(y;ğ³)ğ¼ğ‘¦ğ³I(y;\mathbf{z}) conditioned on ğ³âŸ‚âŸ‚ğœ·\mathbf{z}\perp\!\!\!\!\perp\bm{\beta}. This is to make sure the previous two constraints on ğœ·ğœ·\bm{\beta}, ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u}, and ğ³ğ³\mathbf{z} do not harm prediction performance.

In this paper, we extend the DefinitionÂ C.1 to DefinitionÂ 3.1 by incorporating both client feature index and client label index.

C.2 CLIP

CLIPÂ (Radford etÂ al., 2021) is a cross-modal model that establishes a connection between vision and natural language by projecting image and text embeddings onto a shared space. When presented with an image ğˆğˆ\mathbf{I} and a corresponding descriptive sentence denoted as ğ“ğ“\mathbf{T}, the CLIP image encoder and text encoder encode the image and text into image embedding ğƒğƒ\mathbf{D} and text embedding ğ‹ğ‹\mathbf{L}, respectively. Subsequently, the embeddings ğƒğƒ\mathbf{D} and ğ‹ğ‹\mathbf{L} are aligned to achieve a large cosine similarity, thereby harmonizing the vision and language embedding spaces.

Appendix D Additional Experiment Results

D.1 Workflow of Client2Vec on Language Datasets

In FigureÂ 7, we depict the workflow of Client2Vec on language datasets. The primary distinction between FigureÂ 1 and FigureÂ 7 arises from the methods employed for encoding data and labels. Specifically, for language datasets, particularly in the context of the next character prediction task, the data is encoded as "The next character of {data}", while the label is encoded as "Character {label}". In both cases, the CLIP text encoder is utilized by both the data encoder and label encoder for this task.

D.2 Experiment Settings

Dataset partition.

The dataset partition follows the widely used settings in FL. In detail, we consider three datasets in this paper, and the details are listed as the follows.

  • â€¢

    Shakespeare: The partition of Shakespeare dataset directly use the partition method provided by LEAF benchmarkÂ (Caldas etÂ al., 2018), and we set the fraction of data sample to 0.1, fraction of data in training set is set to 0.8, and minimum number of samples per user is set to 40.

  • â€¢

    CIFAR10: We use the Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA)Â (Yurochkin etÂ al., 2019; Hsu etÂ al., 2019) method with parameter Î±=0.1ğ›¼0.1\alpha=0.1 to introduce label distribution shifts among clients. The dataset is partitioned into 100 clients.

  • â€¢

    DomainNet: We randomly choose 50 classes from the overall 345 classes from DomainNet dataset. Sub-datasets of each domain are partitioned into 10 clients, resulting in 60 clients in total. Images are resized to 64Ã—64646464\times 64.

Training details and hyper-parameters.

For every dataset and algorithm, we randomly select 10% of clients in each communication round and execute a total of 100 communication rounds. We employ the SGD optimizer, with a momentum setting of 0.9 for the DomainNet dataset, and a weight decay set to 5e-5. The number of local epochs is fixed at 5, and the learning rate is set to 1e-2. The experiments are conduct on single NVIDIA 3090 GPU. The hyperparameters for our enhanced case studies are detailed below.

  • â€¢

    Improved client sampling. The heat parameter Ï„ğœ\tau in EqÂ (1) is tuned in [0.1,0.5,1.0,2.0]0.10.51.02.0[0.1,0.5,1.0,2.0].

  • â€¢

    Improved model aggregation. We choose the optimal results by choosing Î³=[0.1,0.5,0.9]ğ›¾0.10.50.9\gamma=[0.1,0.5,0.9], and set Î»1=1.0subscriptğœ†11.0\lambda_{1}=1.0 by default in EqÂ (8).

  • â€¢

    Improved local training. For algorithms without extra local regularization terms, such as FedAvg, FedAvgM, and FedLC, the weights assigned to â„’oâ€‹râ€‹tâ€‹hsubscriptâ„’ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘¡â„\mathcal{L}_{orth} and â„’dâ€‹iâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptâ„’ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{L}_{dist} are explicitly fixed at 1.01.01.0. In contrast, for approaches incorporating additional local regularization terms, such as Moon, FedDyn, and FedIIR, the weights assigned to â„’oâ€‹râ€‹tâ€‹hsubscriptâ„’ğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘¡â„\mathcal{L}_{orth} and â„’dâ€‹iâ€‹sâ€‹tsubscriptâ„’ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘¡\mathcal{L}_{dist} are set equal to the respective values of those additional local regularization terms in the respective algorithms.

Model architectures and training details of DSA-IGN.

The projection layer utilizes a three-layer transformer encoder. Each transformer encoder layer consists of 8 attention heads, with the model dimension set to 32, and the feed-forward layer dimension set to 2048. The projection layer is represented as a matrix with dimensions 1024Ã—51210245121024\times 512. Given a batch of CLIP embeddings ğƒâˆˆâ„NÃ—512ğƒsuperscriptâ„ğ‘512\mathbf{D}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times 512}, the input for the decomposition block is constructed as ğˆi,j=[ğƒ,ğƒ]âˆˆâ„NÃ—1024subscriptğˆğ‘–ğ‘—ğƒğƒsuperscriptâ„ğ‘1024\mathbf{I}_{i,j}=[\mathbf{D},\mathbf{D}]\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times 1024}. Subsequently, ğˆğˆ\mathbf{I} is reshaped into ğˆ~=(NÃ—32Ã—32)~ğˆğ‘3232\tilde{\mathbf{I}}=(N\times 32\times 32), indicating that each sample comprises 32 patches, and each patch has a dimension of 32.

The reshaped ğˆ~~ğˆ\tilde{\mathbf{I}} is fed into the decomposition block, producing an output ğ~âˆˆ(NÃ—32Ã—32)~ğğ‘3232\tilde{\mathbf{O}}\in(N\times 32\times 32), which is then reshaped to ğ=(NÃ—1024)=[ğ™,ğ”]ğğ‘1024ğ™ğ”\mathbf{O}=(N\times 1024)=[\mathbf{Z},\mathbf{U}]. Here, ğ™âˆˆâ„NÃ—512ğ™superscriptâ„ğ‘512\mathbf{Z}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times 512} represents the data encoding ğ³ğ³\mathbf{z} as defined in DefinitionÂ 3.1, and ğ”âˆˆâ„NÃ—512ğ”superscriptâ„ğ‘512\mathbf{U}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times 512} corresponds to the sample feature index ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u}. The input to the projection layer is identical to the output of the decomposition block, represented as ğğ\mathbf{O}.

D.3 Ablation Studies on Client Index Generation

Generating client index w/o the use of the diversity loss â„’dâ€‹iâ€‹vsubscriptâ„’ğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘£\mathcal{L}_{div}.

As shown in FigureÂ 8, the client feature index ğœ·ifsuperscriptsubscriptğœ·ğ‘–ğ‘“\bm{\beta}_{i}^{f} become close to identical when do not use the diversity loss. This result suggest the necessity of using the diversity loss to obtain the meaningful results.

Using different projection layers in DSA-IGN.

In FigureÂ 9, we use single Linear layer and two-layer MLP as projection layers in DSA-IGN. Results show that both architectures can obtain sufficient meaningful results.
